gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Geographic distribution of major crops across the world Global Biogeochemical Cycles

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: Geographic distribution of major crops across the world Global Biogeochemical Cycles

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Center for Sustainability and the Global Environment

gmd:individualName.gco:CharacterString: Leff, B., Ramankutty, N., and Foley, J.A

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Center for Sustainability and the Global Environment (SAGE) 18 Major Crops dataset characterizes the distribution of major crops across the Global Biogeochemical Cycles. The data set was developed using data on proportion of harvested area within each grid cell, and therefore represents, for each grid cell, the probability of finding a given crop in that location during the year. Thus, if a crop is multiple cropped during the year, it has a higher probability of being in a grid cell than those crops that are single cropped, even if they occupy the same "physical" area. Furthermore, the sum of the 18 major crops and the other crops will yield the original Ramankutty and Foley (1998) data set. This implies simplisitic assumptions such as the ignoring of temporary fallow land (also considered cropland), croplands temporarily used as pastures, etc. In summary, this is a global data set intended to provide very rough indications of the probability of finding major crops in different locations across the world in the early 1990s period. [Summary provided by SAGE.] [ This document was provided by NASA's Global Change Master Directory. For more information on the source of this metadata please visit http://gcmd.nasa.gov/r/geoss/[GCMD]SAGE_MAJORCROPS ]

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: This global data set is intended to provide very rough indications of the probability of finding major crops in different locations across the world in the early 1990s period. It was developed to be used for global modeling applications, and should be used with caution.

Geographic distribution of major crops across the world Global Biogeochemical Cycles

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: This metadata record is publicly available.

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Validation of the classification using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples using random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected

gmd19157:valueType.gco:RecordType: Confusion matrix recording counts from ground truthing

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Spatialization of the classification success probability using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples sing random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step). The test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is used to define the dependent variable in the logistic regression model: success/failure binomial variable setting a 2 values reclassification of the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix layer id="LC") and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) i.e., 1=agreement between ClsMix and MCSCtest, 0=disagreement between ClsMix and MCSCtest. Note that the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix layer) and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is actually the spatialization of the Confusion Matrix described in the previous quality report.

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected. However this procedure implies that only 25% of the ground truth area is used in model fitting and then 10% of this 25% is sampled in the statistical model fitting in order to avoid spatial correlation (still 1105303 pixels analysed)

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: This layer is the error model validation layer, i.e. a binomial layer representing coincidence between the values predicted by the logistic regression model and the observed values (either correct/incorrect pixels).
Average success probability for the statistical cluster obtained from linear regression model (object level mean average success probability expressed in %)

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Validation of the linear regression model by replicating the process using as dependent variable the mean probability of success in the validation subsample (this is to say, the 25% test_test areas: MCSC_test_test_12cat). The obtained goodness of fit statistic Adjusted determination coeficient values is similar (0.931). Application of both models and correlation between predicted mean probability of successes (%) between both models' predictions: very similar models, and very close to 1 correlations

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Legend choice is subjective. Some of the original 233 categories have been reclassified as nodata. In the end the % of the MCSC that has been used (with buffering) is 41.38% of the study area. Difficulties in fitting the photointerpretation product legend with a suitable spectral features legend.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: Use of the Habitats Maps of Catalonia -available online from the regional government web- to compare the categories between them and reject the most mixed ones when doubtful.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: Our university used this dataset to monitor changes in the agricultural land use in Spain between 2005 and 2010. We would recommend this dataset for landcover research.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Metadata record is very good. Quality and lineage information is available.
The data is of good quality. Metadata record provides some lineage information.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: The dataset was used to monitor farming land use in the UK between June 2010 and July 2013.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset was used for classification of forests cover in Spain between 2010 and 2013 . We discovered that data for June - August 2011 was missing.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Overall, dataset provides good temporal and spatial coverage. Data is missing for Spain region between June and August 2011.
